questions.text: A 26-year female is to be operated on for a frontal lobe tumor. Her BP is 160/100 mmHg, pulse rate 58 /minute, and on fundoscopy papilledema is positive. All of the following statements are true regarding the anesthetic management of this patient except:

options.label: A
options.text: The patient can be hyperventilated to reduce ICT

options.label: B
options.text: The induction agent of choice is Thiopentone

options.label: C
options.text: The inhalational agent of choice is Sevoflurane

options.label: D
options.text: 5% dextrose is the fluid of choice for maintenance

questions.correct_answer: D. 5% dextrose is the fluid of choice for maintenance
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5% dextrose is the fluid of choice for maintenance Hyperglycemia can cause brain edema and increase cerebral ischemic insult. Colloids can be used safely for a head injury. NS can cause hyperchloremic acidosis while RL contains calcium and is a little hypotonic. Therefore, the best policy is to alternate RL and NS liter by liter

Highyeild:

Colloids can be used safely for a head injury. NS can cause hyperchloremic acidosis while RL contains calcium and is a little hypotonic. Therefore, the best policy is to alternate RL and NS liter by liter

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A. Hyperventilation by decreasing pCO2 decreases the intracranial tension and the effect is immediate. Option B. Thiopentone is an agent of choice for induction in neurosurgery because it not only decreases oxygen consumption and metabolic rate of the brain but also decreases intracranial tension. Option C. Among inhalational agents, a minimum increase in intracranial tension is seen with Sevoflurane making it an inhalational agent of choice for neurosurgery.

Extraedge:

Although hyperventilation is still widely practiced to reduce ICT however, current-day recommendation is in favor of maintaining hypocapnia. Other methods which can be utilized to reduce ICT include diuretics (mannitol, furosemide) {decrease the brain water}, and steroids {decrease ICT by decreasing the production of CSF}.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male is posted for excision of parietal meningioma. Which of the following anesthetic agents can be used safely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Option A. Suxamethonium by causing contractions of neck muscle can decrease the venous return from the brain increasing the ICT, therefore should not be used in neurosurgical patients. Option B . Ketamine can cause up to a 60% increase in ICT. Therefore, it is contraindicated for neurosurgery. Option C . Among inhalational agents maximum increase in ICT is seen with Halothane. Therefore, it should be avoided in neurosurgery.

questions.text: A 22-year male is being operated on for removal of a posterior fossa mass. Surgery was done in a sitting position. After 20-30 minutes of surgery, the patient developed PSVT, and ETCO2 was reduced to 15 mmHg. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Air embolism In a sitting position, the pressure in the dural sinuses is negative. Due to this negative pressure air may be sucked with the opening of the dura causing a venous air embolism. The air may reach the heart causing arrhythmias.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- In accidental extubation, ETCO2 will become zero. Moreover, accidental extubation most often occurs at the time of positioning i.e., before the beginning of surgery. Option C- Anaphylaxis has never been reported with inhalational agents. Moreover, ETCO2 will not reduce in anaphylaxis. Option D- There is no reason for the central anticholinergic syndrome as atropine has not been given to Moreover, ETCO2 will not get reduced in central anticholinergic syndrome

questions.text: A 42-year male is undergoing neck dissection with an elevation of the head end of the table by 20 degrees. Anesthesia was maintained on 75% N2O +25% Oxygen + Sevoflurane. In the middle of the surgery, it was found that patient ETCO2 was reduced from 40 to 20 mmHg. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The anesthetist should immediately reduce Nitrous oxide to 50%

options.label: B
options.text: Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) would have been the most specific test to diagnose this condition

options.label: C
options.text: Patient should be immediately turned to left lateral position to prevent paradoxical embolism

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The diagnosis of this patient is venous air embolism. As the neck veins are above the level of the heart therefore the opening of any of the major veins would have led to air embolism.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect option Option A- Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen, so can significantly increase the size of air embolus. Therefore, it must be stopped immediately, not reduced. Option B- TEE is the most sensitive test to detect air embolism. It can detect as low as 0.2 ml of air however not specific. The most specific is the increase in end-tidal nitrogen. Option C- Left lateral position is not used routinely; it is used only if ASD/VASD is suspected where air can directly reach the left side of circulation to cause paradoxical embolism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female is posted for lower segment cesarean section. Incorrect statement about anesthesia in this patient:

options.label: A
options.text: The dose of local anesthetic should be decreased for spinal

options.label: C
options.text: Induction with inhalational agents is delayed

questions.correct_answer: C. Induction with inhalational agents is delayed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Induction with inhalational agents is delayed Due to the increase in minute volume, induction with inhalational agents is faster

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- Gravid uterus by compressing the IVC leads to engorgement of epidural veins. Engorged veins compress the dura medially decreasing the subarachnoid space and leading to a higher spread of local anesthetic given during spinal. That’s why the chances of high spinal condition are very high in pregnant patients. Therefore, the dose of local anesthetic is reduced by 30-40%. Option B- Due to the sedative effects of progesterone, the MAC of inhalational agents may decrease by 30%. Option D- Due to capillary engorgement (progesterone effect) in the upper airway there may be laryngeal edema making intubation difficult.

questions.text: The most common cause of death of a mother undergoing emergency cesarean section when general anesthesia is being administered is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Acid aspiration of gastric contents
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acid aspiration of gastric contents A pregnant patient is very vulnerable to aspiration (Mendelson syndrome) because progesterone relaxes the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and delays gastric emptying. Gastric contents are also more acidic. Secondly, the gravid uterus changes the angle of the gastroesophageal junction making LES incompetent.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- The overdose of inhalational agents can occur because of the decreased MAC however will not cause death Option B- Circulatory failure can also occur particularly due to supine hypotension syndrome but is not the most common death during GA Option D- Renal failure due to anesthesia during pregnancy is infrequent.

Extraedge:

The chances of aspiration can be 8 times more in pregnant patients as compared to non-pregnant.

questions.text: An 8-week pregnant patient has come for an emergency appendectomy. Anesthesia of choice is:

options.label: B
options.text: GA with ketamine and maintained on O2 + N2O

options.label: C
options.text: GA with thiopentone and maintained on O2 + N2O

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spinal The aim in pregnant patients is to avoid GA as far as possible (especially in 1st trimester) as there is possibility of teratogenicity with anesthetic agents particularly, nitrous oxide. Therefore, the anesthesia of choice is regional anesthesia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female is posted for a cesarean section due to severe fetal distress. However, in history it was found that the patient is fasting for more than 6 hours. As there is no time to give a spinal, the patient received GA. All of the following statements are true regarding GA given to pregnant patients except:

options.label: A
options.text: Volatile agents of the current day can be used safely as they do not produce uterine relaxation

options.label: C
options.text: Non-depolarizers of current use can be used safely

options.label: D
options.text: The patient should be induced with rapid sequence induction

questions.correct_answer: A. Volatile agents of the current day can be used safely as they do not produce uterine relaxation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Volatile agents of the current day can be used safely as they do not produce uterine relaxation All inhalational agents of current use in concentrations > 0.5-1 MAC cause uterine relaxation and increase the risk of PPH.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option B- It is safe to use Suxamethonium because it is rapidly metabolized in maternal plasma by pseudocholinesterase therefore a negligible amount reaches the fetus. This amount is also not dangerous because it gets metabolized in fetal circulation Option C- Non-depolarizes are quaternary compounds therefore do not cross the placenta therefore can be used safely. Option D- Pregnant patients are at such high risk of aspiration that they should be considered full stomach even if they are fasting and all measures to prevent aspiration like metoclopramide and ranitidine prophylaxis, rapid induction with Sellicks maneuver should be taken during GA

Extraedge:

In the past Gallamine used to be contraindicated because it was the only non-depolarizer that had crossed the placenta.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is posted for a cesarean section due to non-progress of labor under spinal anesthesia. All of the following statements are true regarding spinal given to pregnant patients except:

options.label: A
options.text: Wedge must be put under right hip just after giving spinal

options.label: B
options.text: The vasopressor of choice is ephedrine

options.label: C
options.text: The chances of post-spinal headache will be more

options.label: D
options.text: Local anesthetics can attain higher concentration in the fetus

questions.correct_answer: B. The vasopressor of choice is ephedrine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The vasopressor of choice is ephedrine Recent studies have shown that Phenylephrine produces less fetal acidosis as compared to ephedrine making it an agent of choice for the treatment of post-spinal hypotension in pregnant patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options Option A- To prevent supine hypotension syndrome, the pregnant patient should be nursed in the left lateral position. The left lateral position is not possible after the spinal otherwise spinal will become unilateral therefore a 15° wedge is placed under the right hip. Option C- Due to increased CSF pressure, CSF loss will be more increasing the possibility of post-spinal headache Option D- Local anesthetic are bases. Once they reach the fetus, they become non-ionized (due to acidic pH) and cannot come back to maternal circulation leading to toxic accumulations in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents can increase the uterine tone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ketamine Ketamine has been found to increase uterine tone however this effect is significant only at high doses. At the clinically used doses, ketamine does not significantly increase the uterine tone

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options Option B- All inhalational used nowadays are equally effective uterine relaxants Options C and D- Thiopentone and propofol have no effect on uterine tone; neither it increased or decreased.

questions.text: Analgesia after LSCS done is GA can be best achieved with which block?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transverse Abdominal Plane (TAP) Transverse Abdominal Plane (TAP) is very effective in producing post-op analgesia after lower abdominal surgeries like cesarean section or herniorrhaphy. The block is given between the transverse abdominis and internal oblique under ultrasound guidance.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options Options B, and C- Ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric alone will not be able to achieve analgesia after LSCS Option D- Pudendal nerve block can be utilized only for perineal procedures like achieving analgesia for the second stage of labor or episiotomy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient in active labor is scheduled for labor analgesia. All of the following statements are false regarding labor analgesia except:

options.label: A
options.text: Level of block required is up to T4

options.label: B
options.text: Most preferred technique is lumbar + sacral epidural

options.label: C
options.text: Ropivacaine is the local anesthetic of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Painless labor should be started once the labor is fully established

questions.correct_answer: C. Ropivacaine is the local anesthetic of choice
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ropivacaine is the local anesthetic of choice The drug combination of choice is Ropivacaine + fentanyl as an infusion. Due to less cardiotoxicity Ropivacaine is preferred over bupivacaine. Adding fentanyl decreases the dose of Local Anesthetic

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- Pain afferents from the uterus and cervix travel up to T10-L1 so block up to T10 is sufficient. Option B- For painless labor, the continuous lumbar epidural is employed. The double catheter technique is now obsolete because when both stages of analgesia are possible through one catheter then why to put another catheter. Moreover, the chances of contamination of the sacral catheters are very high. Option D- The conventional approach that painless labor should be instituted only once labor is fully established (i.e. if the cervix is at least 3-4 cm dilated) is no more advisable; the current approach is to start painless labor when the patient demands.

Extraedge:

The level of block required for cesarean section is up to T4 due to handling of the gut and peritoneum during surgery

questions.text: A 33-year-old female was given an epidural for painless labor however unfortunately the analgesia achieved was partial. All of the following techniques can be utilized to supplement analgesia except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Morphine Like Local anesthetic, opioids are also bases. Once they reach the fetus, they become non-ionized (due to acidic pH) and cannot come back to maternal circulation leading to toxic accumulations in the Morphine is long acting and therefore has a very high chance of accumulation therefore must not be used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- Remifentanil is rapidly metabolized in maternal plasma therefore very minimal drug crosses the placenta. Moreover, fetus plasma has enough esterase to metabolize remifentanil Option B- Entonox, which is a combination of nitrous oxide and oxygen can be used as an alternative to epidural

questions.text: Anesthesia of choice for cesarean section for pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH):
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spinal The previous concerns of exaggerated hypotension in PIH patients have been unfounded by recent evidence making spinal to be a safer choice for PIH patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Theoretically Epidural has been considered as the technique of choice for PIH patients but practically most often epidural is not feasible for cesarean due to multiple reasons like slow onset (unsuitable for emergencies), patchy block, and inadequate muscle relaxation. Option C- Combined spinal epidural is neither required and almost never used for cesarean section Option D- Giving GA to pregnant patients should be avoided due to the high risk of aspiration. Moreover, associated laryngeal edema in PIH can make intubation become more difficult.

questions.text: A lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) can be carried out under all the following techniques of anesthesia except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Caudal anesthesia Caudal (drug in sacral hiatus) is not recommended for LSCS because: LSCS requires a block up to T4 which is not possible to achieve through the caudal route. Very high chances of contamination (as the perianal region is infected during labor). Accidental injection in the fetal head.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options Option A- GA is given for LSCS due to many reasons like failed spinal, patient refusal, coagulation abnormality, severe fetal distress, and shock due to APH however should be avoided as far as possible due to the very high risk of aspiration Option B- Spinal anesthesia is the anesthesia of choice for cesarean section Option D- Epidural is generally not used however can be used for elective cesarean sections in selected cases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is posted for herniotomy under GA. Incorrect statements about the airway management of this patient:

options.label: A
options.text: Lower placement of larynx as compared to adults

options.label: B
options.text: Use a small size as the larynx is the narrowest part

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option A- In children larynx is placed higher (cephalad) as compared to adults and the epiglottis is large and leafy. Therefore, a straight blade laryngoscope like miller is preferred as it can directly lift the epiglottis. Option B- Appropriate size tube based on the formula Age/4 + 4.5 should be chosen Option C- As per recent evidence there is no difference in subglottic edema and obstruction in cuffed vs uncuffed tubes, therefore nowadays cuffed tubes can be used at any age.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is posted for orchiopexy under GA. The preferred anesthetic for induction will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Propofol The preferred method of induction, irrespective of age is always IV however a significant no. of pediatric patients will not allow IV cannulation therefore they have to be induced by inhalational induction. So, inhalational induction is never the first-choice method of induction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- Among inhalational, Sevoflurane is most preferred due to its pleasant induction Option C- In case of the non-availability of Sevoflurane Halothane can be used as an alternative. Option D- Intramuscular Ketamine can be used for induction as a third alternative if IV or inhalational induction is not possible. I/M ketamine is given in the preoperative room when the child is with the parents

Extraedge:

Desflurane and Isoflurane should never be used for induction because their induction is highly irritating

questions.text: The correct sequence of Minimum Alveolar Concentration in decreasing order:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infant> neonate> Adult Interestingly, the anesthetic requirement of children is more than adults. Maximum MAC in lifetime occurs at the age of 6 months during infancy. Even a neonatal MAC is more than an adult. With every decade MAC keeps on decreasing. After the age of 40, MAC decreases by 6% /decade. So, the sequence of MAC requirements in decreasing order: Infant> neonate> Adult

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is posted for undescended testis and circumcision. Which of the following is not correct regarding the anesthetic management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tube size- 5.5 outer diameter The no. of tube denotes the internal diameter, not the outer diameter. The formula for calculating tube size in pediatric age group (1-14 years): Age (years)/4+ 4.5 So, the size for this child will be 4/4+4.5= 5.5 internal diameter

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options Option A- Nowadays Miller is the preferred blade for children of all ages. However, it can be used in adults but is not preferred. The preferred blade for adults is Macintosh. Option C- The formula for length in children is: Age/2+12 cm 4/2+12= 14 cm Option D- The old-age concept of using uncuffed tubes in children less than 10 years old does not hold true in current-day Nowadays cuff tubes can be used even in newborn babies.

questions.text: Regarding neonatal circumcision, which of the following is true:

options.label: A
options.text: It should be done without anesthesia, as it is hazardous to give anesthesia

options.label: B
options.text: It should be done without anesthesia, as neonates do not perceive pain as adults

options.label: C
options.text: It should be done under local anesthesia only

options.label: D
options.text: General anesthesia should be given to neonate for circumcision as they also feel pain as adults

questions.correct_answer: D. General anesthesia should be given to neonate for circumcision as they also feel pain as adults
questions.explanation:
Solution:

General anesthesia should be given to neonate for circumcision as they also feel pain as adults As it was assumed earlier that children’s pain perception is less as compared to adults but now it has been proven that children feel equal pain as adults therefore circumcision should be performed under general In fact, the majority of the anesthetists are giving caudal along with GA to achieve post-op analgesia in circumcision.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options Options A, and B- It is unethical to do surgery without anesthesia as the pain perception of children is the same like adults Option C- It is not possible to do surgery on a child under local anesthesia. The child will keep on moving during surgery.

questions.text: Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in all, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Option A- In the tracheoesophageal fistula air through the fistula can leak into the esophagus increasing the intragastric pressure Option B- In Meconium aspiration syndrome, the stomach is full of meconium so the child will be treated as full stomach, and bag and mask ventilation will be contraindicated. Option C- Bag and mask ventilation is C/I in Diaphragmatic hernia because air leak into the stomach will lead to distension of the bowel compressing the lung further, worsening the respiratory difficulty and hypoxia

questions.text: A neonate is posted for the diaphragmatic hernia repair. All of the following statements regarding the management of this child are true except:

options.label: B
options.text: Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for maintenance

options.label: D
options.text: Cis-atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice

questions.correct_answer: B. Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for maintenance
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for maintenance Sevoflurane and halothane are the induction agents of choice in the paediatric age group but not preferred for maintenance because they have higher incidence of delirium. Desflurane is most preferred for maintenance because of low incidence of delirium and least metabolism, so least dependent on hepatic functions which may be underdeveloped in children.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options Option A- Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than air therefore can diffuse into the gut and can cause its distension further compressing the lung tissue. Option C- Neonate has developing nerves therefore have extra junctional receptors. Suxamethonium should be avoided due to presence of extra junctional receptors and possibility of presence of some undiagnosed muscular dystrophy. Option D- As Cis-atracurium and atracurium undergoes Hoffman degradation therefore are not dependent on hepatic function and no risk of accumulation making them as muscle relaxants of choice for paediatric patients

questions.text: After surgery under GA breastfeeding should be delayed for:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

24 hours After surgery breast feeding should be delayed for 24 hours

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is undergoing squint correction surgery. The anesthetist is continuously watching the monitor to detect:
questions.correct_answer: A. Bradycardia due to Oculocardiac reflex
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradycardia due to Oculocardiac reflex Manipulation of ocular muscles, particularly medial rectus or pressure in globe can precipitate Oculocardiac reflex which may manifest as bradycardia and can even proceed to asystole. Therefore, continuous cardiac monitoring is necessary during squint surgery.

questions.text: A patient has come for repair of retinal detachment under GA. Surgeon is planning to use Sulphur hexafluoride for the treatment. Which of the following agent drug/drugs will be contraindicated for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option A- Ketamine can increase the intraocular pressure by increasing the tone of ocular muscles Option B- Succinylcholine can significantly increase the intraocular pressure by causing fasciculations of ocular muscles. Therefore, ketamine and Suxamethonium should not be used for ocular surgeries Option C- Nitrous oxide may increase the bubble size of Sulphur hexafluoride to 3 times thus can raise the intraocular pressure significantly. Therefore, N2O must not be used for retinal detachment surgeries if sulphur hexafluoride bubbles are used for treatment. In fact, nitrous oxide should not be used for the next 3 weeks following the surgery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is posted for Panendoscopy. Most preferred technique for Panendoscopy:

options.label: A
options.text: Standard general anesthesia with small size endotracheal tube

options.label: B
options.text: General anesthesia with high frequency positive pressure ventilation

questions.correct_answer: A. Standard general anesthesia with small size endotracheal tube
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Standard general anesthesia with small size endotracheal tube Panendoscopy, previously used to be called Microlaryngeal surgeries (MLS)include removal of vocal cord polyps, taking biopsies for laryngeal growth. In the majority of the patients, standard general anesthesia with small size endotracheal tubes with cuffs (called MLS tubes) is employed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- In some cases, it is only possible to pass a rigid catheter through a narrowed glottic opening so these patients are ventilated by high frequency positive pressure ventilation. Option C and D- Apnea technique (no ventilation during procedure) or insufflation (only oxygenation without ventilation) are not preferred methods as these techniques increase the risk of hypoxia.

questions.text: The anesthetic agent to be avoided for micro laryngeal surgeries (MLS):
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide should be avoided in micro laryngeal surgeries (MLS) because by diffusing through the tube cuff (which is filled with air) it can expand the cuff aggravating the post-surgical edema.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, C- All inhalational agents can be safely used in MLS surgeries. The choice of agent depends on the medical condition of the patient like for cardiac patients Isoflurane will be preferred, for renal patients desflurane will be preferred and for hepatic patients sevoflurane will be preferred.

questions.text: While performing laser surgery for larynx it catches fire, all should be done immediately except:
questions.correct_answer: A. 100% oxygen after discontinuing the anesthesia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100% oxygen after discontinuing the anesthesia As oxygen supports fire therefore air should be used for ventilation

Highyeild:

Many Panendoscopy surgeries use lasers. The most important complication of laser surgery is fire. Therefore, aim should be to prevent fire by taking the following prophylaxis: Use low FIO2 (<30%) Avoid N2O because N2O can support fire Use laser resistant endotracheal tube Fill the tube cuff with saline instead of air In case there occurs fire, the following protocol should be followed : Immediately remove tube and submerge in water Stop oxygen and nitrous oxide start ventilation with air by mask. Flush pharynx with 40-50 ml of cold saline or normal saline if cold saline is not available. Do bronchoscopy to assess the damage and accordingly ventilate the patient with a mask, laryngeal mask airway or by reintubation. Tracheostomy may be required if damage is severe not to allow intubation. steroids antibiotics based on requirement

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is posted for tympanoplasty under GA. Which of the following agents should be avoided for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen. As the middle ear contains air, N2O by diffusing into the middle ear can increase the middle ear pressure leading to displacement of graft and failure of the surgery.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- Volatile agents can be used safely in tympanoplasties.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy aspirated a marble. ENT surgeons are expecting this marble to be in the right bronchus as the right lung is hazy on X-ray chest. The child is posted for removal of marble by rigid bronchoscopy. Anaesthesia of choice for rigid bronchoscopy:

options.label: B
options.text: General anaesthesia with high frequency jet ventilation

questions.correct_answer: B. General anaesthesia with high frequency jet ventilation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

General anaesthesia with high frequency jet ventilation Rigid bronchoscope will occupy the trachea. Therefore, ventilation has to be achieved through the ventilation port of the bronchoscope. This port is too narrow to allow only a few ml of tidal volume. So, minute volume needs to be compensated by increasing the respiratory rate. A special device called high frequency jet ventilation can deliver high frequency (respiratory rate) up to 2000 breaths/minutes. As this small volume is delivered through narrow orifice, a high pressure of 50-60 PSI is required giving it the name of high frequency jet ventilation.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: - Option A- Flexible bronchoscopy is usually done for diagnostic purposes and taking biopsies. It is usually performed under topical analgesia (xylocaine spray) Option C- As a rigid bronchoscope occupies the trachea, intubation is not possible. Option D- Insufflation (means oxygenation without ventilation) is not a desirable technique however is used if high frequency jet ventilation is not available. If a patient starts to desaturate, the bronchoscope is removed immediately and the patient is ventilated with a bag and mask for 2-3 minutes and then again bronchoscopy can be tried and so on.

questions.text: An 8-year boy operated for tonsillectomy developed secondary haemorrhage in the postoperative period. The ENT surgeon wants to re explore to tie the bleeders. All of the following measures should be taken during anaesthesia, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Before induction patient should be nursed in lateral position

options.label: C
options.text: Injection metoclopramide and injection ranitidine before induction

questions.correct_answer: B. IPPV with bag and mask
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IPPV with bag and mask Patients with secondary bleeding from tonsillar fossa are considered as full stomach because they swallow enough blood to cause severe aspiration pneumonitis. Therefore, they should be managed by rapid sequence induction. Bag and mask ventilation is absolutely contraindicated during rapid sequence induction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Lateral position is employed to decrease the risk of aspiration. Option B- All patients undergoing rapid sequence induction must receive metoclopramide and ranitidine. Option D- The only method to prevent aspiration in an intubated patient receiving positive pressure ventilation is the cuff of the endotracheal tube.

Extraedge:

Metoclopramide decreases the risk of aspiration by increasing the tone of lower esophageal sphincter and increasing the gastric emptying time. Ranitidine will not prevent aspiration but will change the pH of gastric contents to less acidic. More is the acidic particle; more is the fulminant reaction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy at a hospital located at a high altitude. For anesthesia given at high altitude, the incorrect statement is:

options.label: A
options.text: Potency of inhalational agents is low

options.label: D
options.text: Rotameter under reads the actual flow rate

questions.correct_answer: A. Potency of inhalational agents is low
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Potency of inhalational agents is low Increasing the barometric pressure increases the anesthetic requirement (minimum alveolar concentration). This is called the pressure reversal theory of anesthesia. At high altitude, due to low barometric pressure MAC decreases and hence the potency increases (MAC is inversely related to potency) however anesthetic depth depends on partial pressure of inhalational agent which remains the same at high altitude.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- The density of gases decreases at high altitude. Due to low density, inhalational agents are delivered in high concentration. Option C- Blood loss is more due to increased venous pressure at high altitudes. Option D- Due to decreased density, the rotameter will read below the actual value of delivered gas.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant patient is posted for a cesarean section under spinal anesthesia at a hospital located at a high altitude. The following post-op complication of spinal increases at high altitudes:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) The CSF pressure increases significantly at high altitudes leading to more loss of CF following spinal anesthesia increasing the incidence of PDPH by 2-2.5 times. Therefore, it's important to use all precautions to prevent post spinal headaches like using fine gauge dura separating needles, and maintaining adequate hydration.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options: - Option B and C- Cauda equina syndrome and transient neurological symptoms are seen with lignocaine which is almost not used for the spinal in present-day clinical practice. Moreover, altitude has nothing to do with the incidence of these neurologic complications.

questions.text: A patient with severe rheumatoid arthritis with cervical involvement is to be operated on for laparotomy. During anaesthesia which of the following should not be done?

options.label: C
options.text: Narcotics and sedatives are to be avoided

options.label: D
options.text: During intubation maintain slight extension at the neck

questions.correct_answer: A. During intubation flexion at neck
questions.explanation:
Solution:

During intubation flexion at neck Patients of severe rheumatoid arthritis with cervical involvement may have atlantoaxial dislocation. Flexion in atlantoaxial subluxation may compress the spinal cord causing quadriplegia or the odontoid process may compress the medulla causing death. Therefore, flexion of the neck is contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Many of these patients will have limited movement of the neck therefore applying the morning sniffing position for intubation becomes impossible. Manipulation of the neck can also be dangerous. Therefore, awake intubation under fiberoptic guidance should be done in this subset of patients. Option C- Narcotics and sedatives should be avoided in patients for whom airway management is difficult otherwise respiratory depression occurring due to narcotics and sedatives can cause hypoxia-related complications including death. Option D- Intubation in these patients should be done either in a neutral position of the neck or with the neck in slight extension.

questions.text: A patient is being operated on for total hip replacement (THR). Just after the implant fixation, the patient developed sudden severe hypotension. The cause may be: Cement reaction Fat embolism Air embolism Blood loss Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct Intraoperative hypotension during THR is a common occurrence. The most common reason for this hypotension was previously considered a cement reaction but now fat embolism or air embolism due to reaming of the femur are also considered equal culprits for causing the hypotension. Blood loss can cause hypotension anytime.

questions.text: A 64-year hypertensive obese female was undergoing surgery for a fractured femur under general anaesthesia. Intraoperatively her end-tidal CO2 volume decreased to 20 from 40 mmHg followed by hypotension and oxygen saturation of 85%. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fat embolism The features are highly suggestive of fat embolism

Highyeild:

Fat embolism is usually seen after a long bone fracture. It becomes more fulminant after reaming of long bones, especially the femur. Usually, it presents after 12-72 hours, however, it can present in an intraoperative period. In a conscious patient, the clinical presentation is dyspnea, restlessness, tachycardia, hypotension, and mental clouding however in GA it usually presents as falling oxygen saturation and a decrease in End-tidal carbon dioxide.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Hypovolemia can decrease end tidal CO2 but spo2 is going to remain normal Option C- ETCO2 remains normal in bronchospasm, only the shape of the graph changes to the shark fin pattern. Option D- ETCO2 and SPO2 are not going to decrease in MI unless it is too massive to cause cardiovascular collapse.

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient underwent femur nailing under spinal anesthesia. 12 hours after surgery, the patient started to complain of respiratory difficulty. Petechial hemorrhages are seen over the chest. The management of this patient includes all of the following, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Steroids There is no role of corticosteroids, heparin, or dextran in current-day practice of management of fat embolism syndrome.

Highyeild:

Fat embolism is a common complication of fracture of long bones. The typical triad of fat embolism syndrome includes dyspnea, mental clouding, and Petechial hemorrhages (over conjunctiva, neck, oral mucosa) however can be associated with hypotension too. The management of fat embolism includes: Adequate oxygenation Mechanical ventilation if needed Judicious fluid management.

questions.text: Tourniquet pressure in lower limb surgery:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100 mmHg above systolic Tourniquet pressure is kept 100 mmHg above systolic and duration should not exceed 2hrs (preferably 90 min) because inflation is more than 2 hrs. can even cause permanent peripheral nerve injury and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with a roadside accident underwent debridement and reduction of fracture of both bone right forearm under axillary block. On the second postoperative day, the patient complained of persistent numbness and paresthesia in the right forearm and hand. The commonest cause of this neurological dysfunction could be all of the following, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Crush injury to hand and lacerated nerves

questions.correct_answer: C. Systemic toxicity of local anesthetics
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Systemic toxicity of local anesthetics Systemic toxicity will have an immediate presentation (not on the 2nd postoperative day) and presentation of systemic toxicity will be lightheadedness, dizziness, tinnitus, perioral numbness, convulsion, coma, hypotension, or any arrhythmia.

Highyeild:

The common causes of neurologic dysfunction in this patient would have been: Injury itself. Surgical intervention. Tourniquet’s excessive pressure or extra time. Tight cast/bandage. Local toxicity of local anesthetics (not systemic toxicity).

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of thromboembolism currently on prophylactic dose low molecular weight heparin has to undergo major orthopedic surgery of the lower limb under combined spinal epidural (patient is unfit for GA due to poor cardiopulmonary reserve). What is the safe time after which a central neuraxial block can be given?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12 hours It is considered safe to give a central neuraxial block after 12 hours of the last dose of LMWH if the dose is prophylactic. If the dose is therapeutic then we can give a central neuraxial block after 24 hours

questions.text: For wake-up test during spinal surgery, all of the following agents can be used, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isoflurane Use of inhalational agents may delay the wake-up test more than 30 minutes therefore inhalational agents are not used for wake up test

Highyeild:

Wake up test is performed to assess the spinal cord function intraoperatively. Anaesthesia is maintained on O2 + N2O + opioid + short-acting muscle relaxant. If nitrous oxide is stopped the patient will become arousable after 3 minutes. So once the effect of the muscle relaxant is over, nitrous oxide is stopped and the patient is asked to move the limbs. Movement of limb exhibits normal spinal cord function. Once movement is tested, the patient is again re-induced and surgery continues.

Extraedge:

With the availability of new techniques like somatosensory evoked potentials to monitor spinal cord function intraoperatively, wake up test is hardly done in present-day clinical practice

questions.text: Match the following Allodynia means: Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b, 2-a, 3-c,4-d Allodynia means non-painful stimulus like touch is perceived as painful by the patient

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Exaggerated response to pain called hyperalgesia. Option C- Pain is desensitized area is anesthesia dolorosa Option D- Persistence of pain after removal of stimulus is hyperpathia.

Extraedge:

Complex regional pain syndromes (CRPS) are painful dystrophies occurring due to increased sympathetic supply to the limb. CRPS has been classified as type II which includes causalgia and type I which includes all other reflex sympathetic dystrophies like burger diseases, Raynaud diseases, sudeck's osteodystrophy, and phantom limb. The typical diagnostic feature of CRPS is an abnormal response to pain like allodynia, anesthesia dolorosa, hyperpathia, and hyperalgesia along with the features of sympathetic overactivity of the limb like hyperhidrosis, swelling, loss of hair, glistening and glossy skin. Non-use of the limb can cause motor weakness and osteoporosis in long-standing cases. The management includes sympathetic blocks like stellate ganglion block or lumbar sympathetic chain block.

questions.text: A 42-year female underwent an open hysterectomy for a very large fibroid under GA. The patient was counseled for an epidural however she strictly refused. The patient was complaining of severe pain in the postoperative period. The staff nurse called the anesthetist who advised to start patient-controlled analgesia. The route of administration of patient-controlled analgesia is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intravenous Patient-controlled analgesia is an automatic system that is connected to an intravenous line. It delivers a fixed amount of drug (opioids) when patients press a button by himself/herself. To prevent overdose a lockout interval is set during which even if a patient presses a button the drug will not be delivered. The advantage of this system is that it avoids delays in the delivery of drugs (the best analgesic effect is seen if the drug is given at the beginning of pain).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Oral route may be sufficient for chronic pain but the intensity of post-surgical pain is high therefore oral administration is not sufficient to achieve analgesia Option B- Local anesthetics + opioids through epidural would have been the best modality to control pain however the patient strictly refused for the epidural. Option D- In modern day practice intramuscular injections must be avoided as far as possible. Moreover, the absorption of opioids from the intramuscular route is unreliable

questions.text: The following scale is commonly used to measure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pain intensity This is a visual analogue scale that is most often used to assess pain intensity. It is a simple horizontal line evenly divided into 10 segments numbered from 0 to 10.0 representing no pain and 10 is the most severe pain. The patient is instructed to mark the number that best describes the level of pain he/she is perceiving. A modified VAS for children includes a continuum of smiling to crying faces or different colors.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options: - Option A- There is no scale used for sleep Option B- Ramsay scale commonly used scale for assessing sedation. Option D- Bispectral index and entropy are used for assessing depth of anesthesia.

Extraedge:

Other than VAS, another popular technique for pain assessment is the McGill pain questionnaire which has five scales for pain (no pain, mild, moderate, severe, and intolerable pain) and instructions to select from a list of 78 sensory and emotional objectives used for describing pain.

questions.text: Massage and liniments to painful areas in the body relieves pain due to:

options.label: B
options.text: Release of endorphins by first-order neurons in the brain stem

options.label: C
options.text: Release of glutamate and substance P

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition by large myelinated afferent fibers

questions.correct_answer: D. Inhibition by large myelinated afferent fibers
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibition by large myelinated afferent fibers Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) and massage work on the gate control theory of pain which states that stimulation of large sensory fibers inhibits the pain pathway between 1st order (dorsal ganglia) and 2nd order neurons (spinal cord) via interneurons, thus closing the gate to pain pathways.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, and B- Massage, acupressure, and acupuncture releases endogenous opioids which also help in controlling the pain however the main mechanism is gate control theory. Option C- Glutamate and substance P increases pain

questions.text: A patient with trigeminal neuralgia with neuralgic pain in the distribution of mandibular division is posted for nerve block. Which of the following statements is true regarding the pain management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Drug of the neurolytic block is 5% lignocaine

options.label: C
options.text: Morphine patches can be given to the patient in postoperative period

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Option A- Pregabalin is the drug of choice for all neuropathic pain except trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgia which responds best to carbamazepine Option B- Neurolytic block (means permanently damaging the nerve) is performed for painful syndromes like trigeminal neuralgia. 5% phenol or absolute alcohol is utilized for neurolytic blocks. Local anaesthetics only produce a temporary block. Option C- Among opioids only fentanyl and buprenorphine patches are available. A fentanyl patch is effective in producing analgesia for 2-3 days while a buprenorphine patch can produce analgesia for 5-7 days.

Extraedge:

Nowadays radiofrequency nerve ablation is preferred over chemical ablation with phenol or alcohol because spillage of drugs can cause permanent damage to nearby structures.

questions.text: For cancer, an opioid can be given through all routes, except: Transdermal Epidural Intravenous oral Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct Depending on the severity, site, availability, feasibility, and cost, for the management of cancer patients, opioids may be given by oral, transdermal (fentanyl patch) IM, SC, IV, sublingual, and epidural routes.

questions.text: Which of the following patients may be considered for daycare surgery? 80-year male for I & D of the thigh 4-year child for circumcision 45-year female with mild hypertension which is controlled on antihypertensives for D & C for endometrial biopsy A 30-year-old healthy patient for laparoscopic cholecystectomy Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct The latest patient selection criteria for daycare surgery now includes all ages except Premature (up to 50 weeks of gestational age) so the patients/surgeries excluded from daycare surgeries are Premature Uncontrolled medical diseases. ASA grading as such is not a criterion and each patient should be selected individually on his/her medical condition however usually, uncontrolled ASA III and above are not considered. The patient was not accompanied by a responsible attendant. Surgeries associated with major hemodynamic shifts. Surgeries associated with the incidence of postoperative complications.

questions.text: In assessing a patient for daycare surgery, it is essential that:

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is accompanied home after the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: A heavy premedication is administered if the patient is nervous

options.label: C
options.text: A blood sample for Hb is always taken

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is starved at least 2 hours prior to the procedure

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient is accompanied home after the procedure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The patient is accompanied home after the procedure The patient who is accompanied by an attendant can only be considered for daycare surgery. Patients coming alone cannot be considered for daycare surgeries.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- As patients are discharged home the same day, premedication should be avoided as far as possible. Premedication should be used if only absolutely necessary and the premedication of choice is midazolam to be given orally 30-60 minutes before or intramuscularly 15-20 minutes before surgery. Option C- Investigations may not be necessary if the patient is clinically fit. Option D- Aspiration is a complication of anesthesia, it has nothing to do with the nature or duration of surgery. Therefore, the patient must be fasting for 6-8 hours even for a 5 minute surgery. Patients undergoing surgery under regional anesthesia also must follow the same fasting guidelines because regional blocks can fail anytime and patients may require GA.

questions.text: Choose the best combination of drugs for daycare surgery:

options.label: A
options.text: Induction- Propofol, Maintenance- sevoflurane, Muscle relaxant – mivacurium, Analgesic - Remifentanil

options.label: B
options.text: Induction- Propofol, Maintenance- Desflurane, Muscle relaxant – mivacurium, Analgesic - Remifentanil

options.label: C
options.text: Induction- Propofol, Maintenance- sevoflurane, Muscle relaxant – Cis- atracurium, Analgesic- Remifentanil

options.label: D
options.text: Induction- Thiopentone, Maintenance- sevoflurane, Muscle relaxant – mivacurium, Analgesic – Remifentanil

questions.correct_answer: A. Induction- Propofol, Maintenance- sevoflurane, Muscle relaxant – mivacurium, Analgesic - Remifentanil
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Induction- Propofol, Maintenance- sevoflurane, Muscle relaxant – mivacurium, Analgesic - Remifentanil Induction - Due to its shorter half-life and antiemetic property (which make the recovery smoother) Propofol is considered as an intravenous induction agent of choice. Maintenance- Although Desflurane has the lowest blood gas coefficient, a recent meta analysis has shown that the difference in recovery time between Desflurane and Sevoflurane is just 1.0-1.2 minutes which is clinically insignificant. Therefore, due to less cost and better respiratory (bronchodilatation, less airway irritation) and cardiac profile (Desflurane can cause tachycardia and hypertension), Sevoflurane is now preferred over desflurane for daycare surgeries. Muscle relaxant- Mivacurium being the shortest-acting non-depolarizer is the muscle relaxant of choice for daycare surgery. Analgesic- Remifentanil being metabolized by RBC esterase, has a short half-life of 10 minutes therefore is the opioid of choice for daycare surgery. Benzodiazepine: Midazolam, having a half-life of 2 hours, is the benzodiazepine of choice for daycare surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following are the criteria to discharge a patient from the hospital after a daycare procedure: Able to eat food Able to maintain vital signs for 60 minutes There is minimal nausea and pain Oriented to person, place, and time Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct Discharge criteria after outpatient surgery are: Able to maintain normal vital signs for 60 minutes. Oriented to person, time, and place. There should be no or minimal nausea and pain. Able to walk without dizziness. Able to pass urine only in high-risk cases of retention like BPH Must be accompanied by a responsible attendant. There should not be active bleeding or any other surgery-related acute complication. Patients not able to accept even liquids can be discharged if fulfilling other criteria of discharge.

questions.text: The most common cause of postoperative admission after daycare surgery is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bleeding Surgical factors like bleeding are the single most important reason for unexpected overnight stay and readmission (overall incidence is 1-6%) of patients after daycare surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Pain is the most important reason for delayed discharge after daycare surgeries Option B- Nausea and vomiting is seen in a considerable no. of patients however most often does not lead to overnight stay. Option D- Respiratory distress can occur however that’s immediate, and usually does not occur after discharge.

Extraedge:

Mild drowsiness is the most common post-op complication of daycare The incidence of mild drowsiness can be as high as 60% however does not lead to delayed overnight stay or readmission.

questions.text: Which of the following gas can be used for laparoscopy? Oxygen Argon Air Carbon dioxide Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct Any gas can be used for insufflation of the abdomen during laparoscopic surgeries however Carbon dioxide is the most frequently used gas for laparoscopy because it is highly diffusible and therefore rapidly eliminated from the body in case of CO2 embolism or pneumothorax. Oxygen because of less diffusibility. risk of oxygen toxicity and inflammability is not preferred Argon, being the inert gas, is the most ideal gas for insufflation in laparoscopy however due to its very high cost, it is not even used in the western world. Air has low diffusibility therefore will get accumulated in a closed space like a pleural cavity in case of accidental pneumothorax which may require even insertion of a chest drain. Moreover, the prognosis of air embolism is poor as compared to CO2. Therefore, air should be the least preferred gas for insufflation.

questions.text: A 40-year female is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. After 5-10 minutes of CO2 insufflation, the patient developed severe hypotension (BP 50/40 mmHg) and tachycardia. ETCO2 showed an initial rise followed by a sudden fall. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CO2 embolism CO2 embolism may occur because of the accidental placement of needles into a vessel during insufflation.

Highyeild:

Large volumes of CO2 in vessels can produce gas lock in the inferior vena cava which can cause severe hypotension or even cardiovascular collapse. Signs of embolism like tachycardia, and right heart strain may become evident. Capnography in the case of CO2 embolism has a typical biphasic presentation i.e., initial rise followed by fall.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B and C- Pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, and pneumopericardium by CO2 may occur during laparoscopy. The presentation is persistent hypoxemia (may or may not be associated with cyanosis), increased airway resistance, and decreased air entry on auscultation. X-ray chest confirms the diagnosis. Option D- Endotracheal tube displacement will immediately produce zero ETCO2 with a flatline graph.

Extraedge:

Transesophageal echocardiography and Doppler are diagnostic tools for CO2 embolism and aspiration of gas or foamy blood from the right atrium is confirmatory.

questions.text: An ASA 1 patient was undergoing Laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It was noticed that ETCO2 decreased to 8mm of Hg, SpO2 became 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure increased to 18mmHg. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumothorax Beyond any doubt, the patient has developed pneumothorax.

Highyeild:

Pneumothorax by highly diffusible gas like CO2 resolves spontaneously in 30-60 minutes. So, chest tube drainage should be reserved only for life-threatening Conservative measures like 100 % oxygen, and reducing intra abdominal pressure improve the hypoxia and are sufficient to manage pneumothorax by CO2 in most cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. In CO2 embolism ETCO2 will show a rise followed by a Moreover, there will not be an increase in airway pressures. Option C. In bronchospasm generally, ETCO2 remains normal, only the graph shows a shark fin pattern. Moreover, hypotension will not be seen in bronchospasm. Option D. ETCO2 will rise and show bifid pattern in endobronchial intubation

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the complications seen during laparoscopy: Increased systemic vascular resistance Decreased cardiac output Bradycardia Increased renal artery pressure Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct Hypercapnia by causing systemic vasoconstriction can increase the systemic vascular resistance Increased intra-abdominal pressure by CO2 insufflation compresses the vena cava which can significantly (up to 30-35%) decrease the cardiac output. Bradyarrhythmia may occur due to sudden peritoneal stretching by CO2 insufflation. Vascular resistance of all abdominal organs (except adrenals) is significantly increased leading to decreased blood flow. The reason for the increased resistance may like: Increased intra-abdominal pressure decreases the cardiac output and renal perfusion which leads to the reflex release of vasopressin and catecholamines increasing the renal artery pressure. Hypercapnia-induced increase in vascular resistance

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is posted for laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy. All of the following statements related to the anesthetic management of this patient are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: General anaesthesia with hyperventilation is preferred

options.label: B
options.text: Intra-abdominal pressure should be maintained between 20-25 mmHg

options.label: C
options.text: Propofol is the induction agent of choice

options.label: D
options.text: most common post-op complication is nausea and vomiting

questions.correct_answer: B. Intra-abdominal pressure should be maintained between 20-25 mmHg
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intra-abdominal pressure should be maintained between 20-25 mmHg Intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) should be maintained between 12-14 mmHg.

Highyeild:

At intraabdominal pressure of 14mmH, cardiac output can decrease by 30-40%. Pressure above 14 mmHg can decrease the blood supply to abdominal organs. At IAP > 20 mmHg cardiac output can decrease by 60-70% which can cause cardiovascular collapse and ischemia of abdominal organs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. During laparoscopy, there is increased pCO2. To eliminate this excessive CO2 mild to moderate hyperventilation is required. Options C, and D. As the incidence of nausea and vomiting during laparoscopic surgeries can be as high as 30-40%, propofol due to its antiemetic properties is the most preferred

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the contraindication for laparoscopic surgery: Increased intracranial tension Ventriculoperitoneal shunt Congestive heart failure COPD Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 3 are correct For respiratory diseases, laparoscopy is better than open surgery as respiratory dysfunction in the postoperative period is significantly less in laparoscopic surgeries. Contraindications for laparoscopy are: Raised intracranial tension (CO2 can further increase intracranial tension). CHF: As the cardiac output is further decreased by pneumo-peritoneum. Patients with peritoneal shunts: Pneumoperitoneum may displace the shunt. Severe hypovolemia and hypotension: As the cardiac output is further decreased in laparoscopy.

questions.text: The most common cause of morbidity and mortality in a patient undergoing major vascular surgery is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiac complications Vascular surgeries (particularly aortic surgeries) are one of the greatest challenges for anesthesiologists because of high morbidity and mortality during vascular surgeries due to cardiac complications which include: Sudden and profuse hemorrhage. Extreme fluctuation in circulatory dynamics. Left ventricular failure due to sudden increase in left ventricular load which is due to aortic cross-clamping. Compromised organ perfusion distal to clamping. Severe hypertension. Myocardial ischemia.

questions.text: A patient operated on for thyroid surgery for thyroid swelling later in the evening developed difficulty in breathing. There was swelling in the neck. The immediate management would be:

options.label: B
options.text: Open the wound sutures in the ward

questions.correct_answer: B. Open the wound sutures in the ward
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Open the wound sutures in the ward Causes of respiratory distress after thyroid surgery are: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. Hematoma leading to compression of the trachea. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy will present as a stridor just after extubation while hematoma will present later in the postoperative period. Immediate treatment of hematoma is opening the neck wound and evacuating the clot and then assessing the need for intubation.
